newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia says listing of dam may be delayed.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia says listing of dam may be delayed.

text.p: A dispute between the main parties building Malaysia's controversial Bakun dam could delay the listing of the dam's operating company, a government official said on Monday.

"It might, it's a possibility," Energy, Posts and Telecommunications Minister Leo Moggie told reporters in reply to a question about a delay in the listing of Bakun Hydro-Electric Corporation (BHEC) after addressing an energy conference.
BHEC is planning to issue 1.5 billion shares at two ringgit (73 cents) each, in what would be Malaysia's biggest public offering.
"If the resolution of this (dispute) involves restructuring, obviously they would have to look at the financing structure," Moggie said.
The 2,400-megawatt capacity dam was originally supposed to have been listed on the Malaysian Stock Exchange in June. It was pushed back to this month because the prospectus was not ready.
Moggie also said the dispute between Ekran Bhd and Asea Brown Boveri over a contract to build the $6.0 billion Bakun dam in the Borneo state of Sarawak should be resolved in "the next month or so".
"I think time is approaching very fast," to keep the Bakun dam construction on schedule for its 2003 opening, he said.
Ekran and ABB had met on July 24 and were supposed to meet again within two weeks. Moggie did not know if there had been a second meeting.

Ekran has said it is unhappy with terms in the contract that require it to absorb any cost overruns associated with the dam, which will create a reservoir as large as Singapore and would be Asia's second-biggest hydro-electric project.
Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has vowed the dam will be built and said the contract could be broken if the terms were found to be unfair.
"Until we hear the final report (after the second meeting) we won't have a formal statement about what the resolution will be," Moggie said.
Ekran had not notified his ministry about possibly pulling out of the project. "We've only heard stories and rumours about Ekran pulling out," Moggie said in reply to a question.

The government would step in to mediate only if there was a deadlock, Moggie added. "I would not want to say anything public that would jeopardise the discussions (between ABB and Ekran). "We have some ideas on how to resolve it in the best possible way if the parties can't solve it themselves."
ABB's chief executive officer, Goran Lindahl, said last week the project would go ahead. "We need a little massaging to get all the details together," he told Reuters in Zurich.
The Bakun contract is the largest ever awarded to the Swiss-based power engineering company, with the value exceeding $2.5 billion.
ABB is implementing the contract in a consortium with Brazil's Companhia Brasileria Projectos Obras (CBPO).

The contract calls for the consortium to supply six 420 megawatt hydro-generators, a 500-kv high voltage direct-current transmission system and install a 650-km (400-mile) submarine cable -- by far the longest in the world -- to connect the dam to peninsular Malaysia.

Ekran has a 32 percent stake in BHEC. Other key shareholders are the federal government's Employees Provident Scheme, state-owned Tenaga Nasional Bhd, the government's investment holding company Khazanah Holdings Bhd, the Sarawak state government and Sarawak Electricity Supply Corp.

Altogether, the stock and rights offerings would raise a total of six billion ringgit. The rest of the dam's financing is expected to be raised through borrowings, analysts said. ($ = 2.724 Malaysian Ringgits)
